newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Northeast spot power steady on cool weather.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Northeast spot power steady on cool weather.

text.p: Spot electricity prices in the northeastern U.S. were steady Friday amid flat regional power usage due to continued mild weather and predictions temperatures are headed even lower, market sources said.

"Load is still low," said one Northeast trader, adding the amount of generating capacity in the region has been sufficient this summer despite outage of two nuclear power facilities operated by Northeast Utilities (NU).
The capacity of NU's Millstone and Connecticut Yankee total 3,282 megawatts (MW). The plants were shut because of safety concerns raised by regulators.
A sharp drop in natural gas prices this week depressed the incremental fuel costs for producing power in the Northeast, traders said.
In the New England Power Pool (NEPOOL), firm, peak electricity for weekend delivery at NU's Conn.-N.Y. border was quoted at $20.00-$23.00 per megawatt hour (MWh), market sources said.
Weekend NEPOOL electricity for firm, off-peak delivery was discussed in the $17.00 area.
Firm, peak NEPOOL prices for Monday was assessed at $25.00-$27.00.
There were still transmission constraints to move power from New York to New England, traders said.
"The Central-East is still a problem," said another Northeast trader, referring to congestion on the main N.Y.-New England power line due to high demand.

In the New York Power Pool (NYPP), firm, peak electricity for weekend delivery was quoted at $18.00-$19.00 per MWh, while off-peak, firm prices for the weekend was pegged in the $16.00-$17.00 range, traders said.
Firm, peak NYPP electricity for Monday was valued at $22.00-$24.00.
